  1. I didn't like the medicinal smell and it didn't do anything for my flakes after a month of use.
  2. I have a super sensitive scalp and have tried tons of shampoos over the years, from mass-market brands to salon products and natural remedies, too. This is the first one I've gone back to purchase again, despite the fact that it's a bit pricey. It's done a great job of settling down my reactive skin (no funny chemicals or allergenic issues), and unlike some other natural shampoos, it still has a great lather, a nice herbal smell and actually leaves my hair looking nice (though perhaps not as smooth as I would like...hence the deduction of 1 star). Also, I have color-treated hair and this shampoo doesn't make it fade (unlike some others I've tried).<br />If you've had similar trouble finding an all-around good shampoo, I would definitely recommend giving this one a try.

  39. In addition to dermatitis, I suffer from severe allergies to fragrance and most of the ingredients in chemical-ridden retail products - from laundry detergent to dish soap to makeup. So I was pretty much forced to find natural alternatives and homemade solutions. I've tried hundreds of products over the last several years that claimed to be organic or natural - and did a good job of hiding the yucky stuff lurking in their ingredients that ultimately caused yet another allergic reaction for me - not pretty or fun. I've gotten more and more educated about what to look for - but it's still a struggle.<br /><br />The dermatitis on the my scalp is embarrassing and uncomfortable. No treatment, prescription or natural product can eliminate it ... just keep it in control and at bay. There is no magic cure. But I've been using Sage shampoo for just over 3 months now and I hardly notice my dermatitis anymore. I can wear dark colors again - I'm not embarrassed to get my hair cut and I'll let the stylist massage my scalp - I&#34;m not itching my head all the time - I have a lot more confidence and one less thing to worry about. I love it!<br /><br />I don't use it every day ... only about 3 times per week. And I don't use shampoo at all the other days, only a conditioner for my hair that I try not to let touch my scalp. I have not had any allergic reaction - it's working! Give it at least a couple of weeks of regular use before you decide if it's working for you or not. But you should notice a difference after the first few shampoos.<br /><br />Drinking a lot of water ( 2 liters or 64 oz. per day) is another tip for dermatitis sufferers. Stay hydrated - don't let your body or your skin 'dry out'.

It’s incredibly frustrating because I've never seen it and it consumes a great deal of time to treat. I suspect the Sodium Lauryl Sulphate in these shampoos was a contributing irritant. I use the Sage shampoo 1x daily and follow that by spraying my head with apple cider vinegar, let sit for 1-3 mins and rinse that off, then rinse finally with really cold water. Lastly, I briskly brush my scalp with a brush to losen any flakes maybe every few days. This seems to control my dandruff and itch, YAY! And the shampoo does smell nice and spicy as described. I looked up all the ingredients in the Sage shampoo and they're all natural based, and gentle. . . worth every penny.

  88. I've struggled with Dandruff since childhood. You know that scene in Breakfast Club where the chick etches a picture of a house on her black desk and fluffs her hair to sprinkle on &#34;snow&#34;? As a child-young adult, I had enough dandruff issues to do just that. Because of my dandruff issues, my acne never went away. If you aren't familiar with this, allow me to explain. There are many ANNOYING factors that cause acne. Bad hygiene, genetics, hormone, stress, and overall health. Although many of these are out of your control, there are things you can do to minimize acne. I've searched everywhere for answers. I'm taking vitamin supplements, bought tea tree oil, mud masks, scrubs, and moisturizers. However, I started to notice that although my skin was very soft and moist, my acne didn't go away. Mainly, the acne on my forehead. Further research and many months of low self esteem later, I came to the conclusion that dandruff was to blame. Clinically speaking, if your acne is more prominent on your forehead, check your shampoo and scalp health.<br />Well, as it turns out, dandruff does cause acne. It prevents your forehead from sloughing off skin cells. So, I purchased this in the hopes that my final war against acne may take place. Guess what? Dandruff is reduced almost by 70% after the first use. The smell is wonderful. Unlike many guys, I don't like smelling like Axe or Old Spice. Sage smells just as good to me. Plus, if you want to attract a potential date, you don't want to smell like every other guy. All in all, I'm happy that I purchased this. It beats Head and Shoulders by a mile. I've used H&S since childhood and my dandruff never stopped.

  124. I am 43 and never had problems with my scalp until about 2 years ago. I am contributing it to hormonal changes in my body. After being told by my dermatologist that I had dandruff I tried the shampoo she recommended which just caused my scalp to become very irritated and itchy. I tried several different brands over the next few months. Some were not as irritating as others, but none were really helping with the itch. Not to mention I was having to wash it everyday just to keep it under control. My hair is thick and long and the time I was having to spend styling it was just too much. So I began my research....and to maybe save you some time, I will tell you what worked for me. I wash my hair in warm (not hot) water, being sure to gently massage it into the scalp and let it sit for a couple of minutes. Rinse and repeat. It doesn't take much, so the bottle goes a long way....and I have long, thick hair. Next, I condition with their Silk 18 condiioner. I am careful to keep the conditioner only on my hair to keep contact with the scalp minimal. I let it sit for a couple of minutes and rinse...finishing with a cold water rinse to close the cuticles. Blow dry with cold air only. If I dont have time to completely blow dry, I at least dry the hair closest to the scalp, so moisture doesnt sit there. I just recently began using the Silk 18 conditioner because I figured out if I used any conditioner at all it was making the back of my head feel greasy after one day. So I just wasnt using anything which made drying and styling my hair very difficult, not to mention my stylist said I was stripping all the color right out of my hair. I tried the conditioner and detangler my stylist told me was top of the line and had no chemicals first. The itching came right back, so I decided to try the MH Silk 18 conditioner. Now I only have to wash my hair every 2--3 days. Bottom line, I think all the chemicals in the other products were making my scalp irritated and itchy. I am so happy I found this product and will probably try some of their other products as well.. I am so happy I found this product and will probably try some of their other products as well.

  168. I have to admit, I was skeptical about this product given my long standing dandruff issues and poor experiences with other anti-dandruff hair care products. So I've learned there are two kinds of dandruff: small, fine flakes from dry scalp and oily larger scaly flakes from fungal dandruff. I struggle with both issues as most people with dandruff do. I've read that its a problem of most sulfate based products overdrying your scalp, causing small flakes, then our scalp overcompensates and overproduces oil feeding the fungal dandruff. I've tried many scalp moisturizing shampoos, leave in treatments for the dry flakes and also many an antifungal sulfide based shampoos to try to combat this issue. I honestly hate most shampoos marketed as anti-dandruff shampoo because they leave my scalp feeling even more dry and unbearable than before using them. Be that as it may, I was willing to give the Sage shampoo a shot since I was getting a sample and it is also sulfate/paraben free. The first thing I noticed after applying this product on my hair for the first time was there was none of that unpleasant medicated dandruff shampoo scent that most antidandruff shampoos come with. It had a nice sage scent that was fragrant but not overpowering. It also lathered up nicely for a sulfate free product. After drying, I noticed that it did not leave my scalp feeling as dry other anti-dandruff shampoos do. I've used this product a few times now and while I have not noticed any scaly fungaly flakes I still have some small flakes from my scalp still being a little dry (it's also the dead of winter right now for me). I think this shampoo did a nice job considering. I know the dry flakes will have to be combatted with a more hydrating shampoo and I'm considering trying out their hydrate shampoo and alternating between the two. A nice bonus of this shampoo I've also noticed is that it leaves my hair feeling very clean and light which I have quite enjoyed. I would definitely recommend this product to anyone with dandruff issues looking for an alternative shampoo without all the usual harsh ingredients. 4.5 stars!

  248. I was like so many others who suffer from really bad dandruff and couldn't find anything that worked. From chemical shampoos to organic apple cider vinegar, believe me I have tried it all. I decided to give this a go in August of 2014. It took about a month of using this product consistently and really following the directions. (Washing your hair twice every shower, letting it sit on the scalp for at least 5 minutes and then repeating, as well as a cool water final rinse before being done). The cool water rinse is really important. I have noticed that my head gets itchy and dry when I just wash in hot water. It's not that you can't have a hot shower just rinse your head in cool/cold right before you get out to close the hair follicle. I started noticing a big difference after just the first few washes however it took about a full month or longer for the dandruff to go away completely. Its now March 2015 and I'm on my 4th bottle and flake free. It's worth every penny!

  409. This product contains DMDM Hydantoin, which is an antimicrobial formaldehyde releaser preservative. This ingredient is classified as a high hazard on the Environmental Working Group's Skin Deep Database. Such a high-hazard ingredient, in my opinion, has no place in a product that touts its natural and organic ingredients and is made by a company with the word &#34;Holistics&#34; in its name. The product also contains Triethanolamine, which is classified as a medium hazard in the EWG's Skin Deep Database. I would urge anyone interested in avoiding high-hazard ingredients in their cosmetics to look up each ingredient before buying. There are many companies engaged in &#34;greenwashing,&#34; and Maple Holistics is apparently one of them.

I would definitely recommend this product, though with its higher price tag, I have chosen to alternate it with a more inexpensive sulfate-free shampoo, with good results.

  513. Background: I've been using various dandruff shampoos for over a year now to try and tame my itchy, oily, uncomfortable and (frankly) ugly scalp issues with limited success. I have chest-length dark wavy hair and the yellowy/white waxy dandruff, bumps and constant itchiness were really doing a number on my self-esteem while the Rx (ketoconazole 2%) and drugstore options (head & shoulders, neutrogena t-sal, selsun blue naturals, nizoral a-d) were doing a number on my hair and helping, but not getting rid of my scalp issues. Even with huge amounts of conditioning even during shampooing, my ends were getting really dry, split and battered from the very harsh shampoo and I wanted to try something without all the detergents. I'd love to be able to dye my hair again without having dandruff shampoos strip the color right back out. Pros of this product: I like that they're very clear what ingredients are for which purpose and the lack of harsh surfactants (detergents), my hair is left very shiny, soft and bouncy after washing and it doesn't seem to mess with my curl pattern or to dry out my ends. The itching is cut down considerably the day of shampooing and well into the day after, which is a huge win for me since even right after shampooing with the very strong Rx shampoo, my head would still be itchy right after the shower. I've seen a decrease in my dandruff and I feel like there might be fewer bumps but I've only been using it for a couple of weeks. Cons: Price is much higher than I'm used to spending for shampoo but my options are limited if I want a dandruff shampoo that I can use once I color my hair. I understand that the ingredients aren't cheap, but do look at the Oz size so you're not surprised by the size of the bottle when it arrives. I'm considering shampooing with another mild, cheap shampoo first and then following with this one to see if I can get the same benefit without using as much product but if that doesn't work then I'll deal with the price since it helps my itchiness and won't strip color. The smell is strong and isn't my taste. It is very earthy, herbal and almost tea-like and I can put up with it since I'm pretty sure it comes with the ingredients and isn't just an added fragrance. It's very strong when you're in the shower and does linger in dry hair more than I'd like. Overall: Worth a shot for those who are tired of the drugstore options and looking for something less harsh but still effective. Awesome for those who like earthy/spicy scents and workable for those who don't. I'll see if it keeps delivering once I dye my hair again but based on my experience so far, I think it's gentle enough that it'll work well and I plan to repurchase when I run out. EDITED TO ADDRESS HAIR DYE COLOR ISSUE 1/10/15: So I bumped this down a star because it is not as color safe as I was hoping it'd be. I dye my brown hair a deep red and although reds are known to fade fast, it definitely strips more color from my hair than a regular sulfate-free shampoo does. Salon color is not cheap and it fading even faster than usual is really not okay with me. Part of the stripping may be due to the fact that the directions have you leave it on your scalp for a while in the shower, but I think even double washing with a very mild shampoo is probably better for my color than using this shampoo. I used a full bottle and was partway into my second bottle when my stylist mentioned that my color was way more faded than it should be if I was using a sulfate-free shampoo. I'm leaving 4 stars because it's a good product otherwise, but proceed with caution or use rarely with dyed hair.

The sage shampoo sure smells nice and it definitely does work against dandruff, but that's where the benefits end for me.<br /><br />After washing my hair with this, it feels hard and doesn't have the smooth and silky feeling I expect from clean hair. I feel like I need to wash it again at the end of the day, even though with other products washing it a couple of times a week is sufficient for me. Sage does not remove my dandruff completely, however, the flakes are much smaller and less in quantity, and it doesn't have any harmful ingredients of many other shampoos. Thus, it does not cause hair fall like some other shampoos I tried. The best thing is that I don't have to use a conditioner separately, as my hair (mens short) is pretty well conditioned with just this shampoo, and it also has a pleasant smell. I use Nizoral occasionally, which is stronger for dandruff but has more harmful ingredients, when I really need to reduce dandruff totally for a day, but it does not leave the hair feeling smooth. I have found my perfect balance in Sage, after looking for a long time.

I went back to their website to see if there was a product that could address both these issues at once and came across the Sage Shampoo. So here's what I like about the shampoo:<br /><br />1) It is awesome on dandruff! Since using it, dandruff has ceased to be a problem for me. I no longer have to worry about a dry, itchy scalp, and my hair is soft and shiny.<br /><br />2) Hair strand loss: I have literally gotten to the point where I can count the strands that I lose per shower! On average, since using this shampoo, I lose about 15-25 stands TOPS. This is an extreme change from feeling like I'm going bald each time I showered in the past.<br /><br />3) It smells wonderful! I love the way my hair smells, and the aroma therapy benefits in terms of waking me up and getting my day started by inhaling the wonderful smell of sage and tea tree oil is a treat to which I look forward every morning.<br /><br />One tip: the attached card tells you to finish your shower with a blast of cold water to seal the cuticle. I cannot stress how much of a difference this makes. On the days that I remember to do this, my strand loss is down to the lower end of the scale.<br /><br />I think I've found my new shampoo. I will no longer buy in store again!

I fell in love within 3 shampoos. It took my hair about a week to get used to the new product and I must say that my hair and scalp have never been softer or more healthy (I couldn't stop running my hands through the soft, untangled length). It rinses clear even in my hard water and I've learned that less is definitely more when it comes to using the product (about a dime size massaged between the palms and rubbed on my scalp then massaged/rinsed down my collar-bone-length hair). I completely used up the first bottle and wanted to purchase more, but was a little taken aback by the purchase price of over $17 for an 8 oz bottle.   684. After seeing all the rave reviews, I still wasn't convinced this would work so well... but it does.<br /><br />I've been using Head & Shoulders products for forever to relieve my persistent, inherited dandruff. They've worked OK, but I've noticed that after using them for so many years, their effectiveness on my scalp just isn't what it used to be. After seeing initially good results, I was still getting quite a bit of dandruff.<br /><br />This shampoo has reduced my dandruff to the lowest levels it has been since I started having scalp dryness. I don't get dandruff at all anymore, except for a tiny piece of dry skin or two once a day (compared to 20+ tiny flakes on a normal day before). My dandruff wasn't super severe, so I wasn't sure if I should buy this shampoo or the tea tree oil shampoo for moderate dandruff. I looked at the ingredient list and saw that they were very similar, but the sage one was a bit stronger. I decided to go with the sage one and it has been an excellent choice.<br /><br />The shampoo smells good (but I like hippie products/smells). It lathers fairly nicely--it doesn't lather up as much as a store-bought shampoo or Head & Shoulders, but I think that is partly why it's so effective. As a girl with longer hair, I just use a little more than a teaspoon and can wash all of my hair effectively. If my hair is really dirty or greasy, I'll mix in some other shampoo to get a better lather.<br /><br />The 8 oz bottle will last me around 3 months. I have medium thickness, longer hair so if you have shorter hair it will last you a good deal longer.<br /><br />I recommend following the product instructions exactly as written. Be sure to leave the product in your hair for at least a couple minutes to let the sage and other oils soak in, and try to rub it into your scalp as much as possible. Rinsing out my conditioner with cool water also helps reduce irritation. I will definitely continue to buy this shampoo since it works so well.
  685. I have seborrheic dermatitis...somewhat worse than dandruff as it affects both skin on your face and especially your hair. I've dealt with it my entire life. I've used EVERY shampoo over the counter and have used numerous shampoos from the Dermatologist with little to no improvement. I'm African-American and do not wash my hair every single day as is suggested by a lot of the dandruff shampoos. After using Sage, I can honestly say this is the BEST shampoo I've used for my scalp. I used it one week ago and have seen minimal flakes. Dandruff can make you incredibly self-conscious and it is so embarrassing...it'll even change the colors that you choose to wear. I pray that I continue to have great results from this shampoo....if so, I'll be using it indefinitely.

  692. it has helped to control dandruff and get rid of itchy scalp.. but don't need to use it everyday.. in the winters especially if you live in a cold dry climate, try to only wash your hair every 2nd or 3rd day and allow the natural oils in your scalp lubricate your skin. Overwashing with most shampoos just irritates the scalp more is my experience. Rinsing off hair and scalp with lukewarm to cold water has also helped to close the pores down. My hair stylist also recommends blow drying your hair (at least for those with oily hair) to help keep your scalp pores from getting clogged if you allow that damp hair to sit on your scalp for too long.

  772. I meant to write this review a week into trying this product because I wanted to test it out a bit before reviewing but ended up forgetting. So instead of a week of trying, I've been using this product for about a month straight (minus a few days) and can honestly say this is how it works. For those who don't like long reviews: Pros: It goes a long way. Lathers well. Fast results. Lessens the dandruff with continuous use. Makes your hair a little less dull in color. (?) Neutral: The smell. If you like tea tree oil/sage than you'll love this but if you don't then you might not. But it is allot better option then the chemical smell you get with most dandruff shampoos. Cons: Expensive. Makes your hair a little tough sometimes when washing out the product. Doesn't get rid of the dandruff. First, I would like to point out that I had bought the 8 oz version and I still have a half of bottle left. I use a quarter amount (or a little more, especially if I wash twice) every wash so considering that, this shampoo goes a long way. Which is especially good for the price and makes it a great product, that is if only it got rid of the dandruff. To give a little background on my history with dandruff I've had been dealing with it for about a year. This is the first time I've actually dealt with this problem for such a long period of time and being so I've come to realize how awful it can really be. To itching all day, to those annoying flakes that start appearing everywhere much to my embarrassment, I've had a horrible time dealing with it. So horrible that I was becoming desperate with getting rid of it. That's when I started using products that were meant to \\"get rid\\" of it. But alas, none of them worked. The cheap store brand shampoo I used only helped calm it down (which was what this shampoo did, except this one is much much more expensive.) and the home remedies (I said I was desperate didn't I?) were awful to experience with and didn't give any results at all. (Let's just say sitting with yogurt in your hair for an hour isn't the funniest thing you could do with your time.) So after awhile of fail after fail, I came on amazon to look up products and their reviews. I thought that if the reviews were good enough, that the product might actually work. There were actually quite a few more products rated higher then this one but what caught my eye was that this was a more \\"natural\\" way of getting rid of dandruff. And knowing that allot of the other products were probably not the safest thing to put on your hair, I decided to go with this one. With all the good reviews and the fact that is was sulfate free (I've been wanting to go sulfate free with shampoos for awhile now), I didn't think I had anything to lose. I wasn't the keenest on the price ($8 is allot for a shampoo to me) but I thought that since people said it worked well and that of course shampoos that are more natural will cost more, I cringed my way to the checkout, ordered it, died a little on the inside, and then waited patiently for it to arrive. The product came 8 days later and I used it right away. The shampoo had a somewhat thick consistency and the smell is exactly like what you would expect, tea tree oil and sage. And though allot of people said it smelled strong, I have to disagree. Sure it makes your bathroom smell like a herbal store (which could be a plus or a minus) but when used it your hair it leaves only a slight smell behind. When using, it lathers well which I liked because unless it suds, I don't think it works. It doesn't make your hair soft but rather ruff/hard and so you might have to fight your way through with your fingers at the end of the wash. But weirdly this can be a thing that only happens in some washes, other times it leaves your hair the same way when using other shampoos. Here are the directions of the shampoo that I followed when using: Rinse hair, massage quarter sized-amount throughout scalp, allow the therapeutic benefits a few minutes (2-3) to osmose before rinsing. Repeat and follow with a final rinse. Tips: Use warm water throughout the duration of the shower. Finish off with a blast of cold water to seal the cuticle. Looking back I realize that I didn't wash twice every time either. But I don't think that would effect the results or change them. I will do so with the rest of the product just in case. The very first morning I felt a HUGE difference. The dandruff wasn't gone all the way and the itching was slightly there but it was so much less than before. The flakes were also all but almost gone. I was about sold with this product. Gone almost in just one wash? YES. This made me think that in a few more washes, the dandruff would be completely gone! A few washes later... Nope. The results were the same, which is good and all since it makes the dandruff less horrible but I bought the shampoo to get rid of the dandruff, not to lessen it. Then one night I decide not to take a shower and when I woke up the dandruff was right back to it's horrible state. So I made sure to take a shower each day but I got the same results. It lessened it when I used it and when I stopped it just came back. So while this shampoo was a great concept in the beginning, in the end it didn't do anything different than what every other shampoo I've tried in this category does. Which is a bit disappointing, especially for the price. Though it does says money back guaranteed but even then I don't know if that means if the products doesn't work at all. UPDATE: After reaching out with an email to Maple Holistics about the product and results, they emailed me back within minutes with an offer to try another product absolutely free and gave me back my full refund. Can I just say wow? I don't think I've ever dealt with a company this awesome and hassle free. If I could give you 5 stars for customer service, I would! So in the end, I would suggest not buying this product unless you're looking for an instant and temporally relief for just a bit. If I end up finding another product that works well with getting rid of dandruff, I will post it in this review.
  773. I have been on topical steroids for a scalp condition for about 6 months now. Nothing has been working. I've tried over the counter anti-seborrheic and anti-dandruff shampoos, and still, nothing has worked. This shampoo in about two weeks has made such a huge difference. My scalp no longer appears to be coming off into my hair, and the front part of my scalp is no longer driving me insane with itchiness. The back part of my scalp has improved, and I imagine in another few weeks will also be drastically better much like the front part. I hope Maple Holistics never stops making this product, it's a life saver.

I tried tea tree shampoo and that makes my scalp tingle and feel clean but its scent is too strong. So I tried this shampoo and conditioner.<br /><br /> The shampoo doesn't tingle, still my scalp and hair is very clean. Its scent is barely there, not too strong.   921. Honestly, I don't know where the good reviews come from. My family have used natural hair and skin care products for years, and this product is just a marketing trick. The essential oils are well chosen for dandruff in theory but in practice the amount here is not enough to make any difference in my husband's dandruff (which responded very well to the Jason anti-dandruff shampoo). I only use anti-dandruff shampoos on occasion for a deeper cleaning of buildup, but after I used this unappealing product, I had an afro! Super drying and frizz producing. And I didn't have the clean-scalp feeling I was after. There is also nothing homeopathic about this product, if you have any idea what homeopathy or homeopathic remedies are about.

Does not have a high concentration of tea tree oil based on my experience as I don't feel the sting on my scalp. Not saying that having a high concentration is a bad or good thing. But its just that if you want something that has a high concentration of tea tree oil, I don't think this is the right product.<br />Almost tempted to go non-organic and get paul mitchell's version of shampoo.<br />Not all dandruff can be completely be solved with just topical solutions though as far as I know of. High concentrations of chlorine can dry your skin and hair for example. An under-active thyroid and dry your skin as well. Getting too much omega-6 oils in relation to your omega-3 oils can also cause issues, as well as fungal infections. Genetics might even play a role and even simple dehydration. Shampoo companies and hair and barber shops tend to push topical solutions to dandruff and dry scalp. But really the problem is a lot more complicated than just using using a shampoo.
